official-title.#text: To direct the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to recognize tinnitus as a mandatory condition for research and treatment by the Department of Veterans Affairs, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

action-desc.#text: Reported with an amendment, committed to the Committee of the Whole House on the State of the Union, and ordered to be printed

action-instruction.#text: Strike out all after the enacting clause and insert the part printed in italic

action-desc.#text: Reported with an amendment, committed to the Committee of the Whole House on the State of the Union, and ordered to be printed

short-title.#text: Tinnitus Research and Treatment Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

The Secretary of
			 Veterans Affairs shall recognize tinnitus as a mandatory condition for research
			 and treatment by the Department of Veterans Affairs Auditory Centers of
			 Excellence.

header.#text: Recognition and treatment of tinnitus at Department of Veterans Affairs Auditory Centers of Excellence

text.#text:
The Secretary of Veterans Affairs shall
			 ensure that research is conducted at Department of Veterans Affairs facilities
			 on the prevention and treatment of tinnitus. Such research shall
			 include—

header.#text: Research on prevention and treatment of tinnitus

text.#text: an assessment of the efficacy of multidisciplinary tinnitus treatment modalities on different subsets of patients;

studies on the underlying etiology of tinnitus in veteran populations that occur as a result of different causal factors, including blast-related tinnitus where there is no measurable hearing loss versus other forms of noise-induced tinnitus where there is hearing loss; and
a study of the underlying mechanisms between hearing loss and tinnitus, including cases in which one or the other condition is present, but not both.

The Secretary of Veterans Affairs shall ensure the cooperation of the Department of Veterans Affairs with the Hearing Center of Excellence established by the Department of Defense to further research on tinnitus.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Tinnitus Research and Treatment Act of 2013

short-title.#text: Tinnitus Research and Treatment Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
Since 2006, the most prevalent service-connected disability for which veterans have received compensation under the laws administered by the
The number of veterans receiving such compensation for tinnitus has risen each year since 2006, increasing the number and cost of the compensation claims paid by the
A growing body of peer reviewed literature indicates a direct connection between traumatic brain injury, post traumatic stress disorder, and tinnitus.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: concluded that total amount of disability compensation paid for tinnitus by the

text.#text: An analysis of data collected by the
Based on projected rates of growth, the amount of disability compensation payable to veterans for tinnitus is expected to exceed $3,000,000,000 in 2017.

Research on prevention and treatment of tinnitus

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall recognize the need to enhance the research and treatment of tinnitus and to ensure the allocation of appropriate resources directed at the research and enhanced treatment of tinnitus conducted by the
, commensurate with peer-review protocols. Such research shall include—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Auditory Centers of Excellence of the Department of Veterans Affairs

text.#text: The
an assessment of the efficacy of multidisciplinary tinnitus treatment modalities on different subsets of patients;

studies on the underlying etiology of tinnitus in veteran populations that occur as a result of different causal factors, including blast-related tinnitus where there is no measurable hearing loss versus other forms of noise-induced tinnitus where there is hearing loss; and
a study of the underlying mechanisms between hearing loss and tinnitus, including cases in which one or the other condition is present, but not both.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to conduct research in accordance with peer-review protocols in order to ensure the quality and transparency of the research.
